Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: N2Women Student Travel Support for the 2016 SIGCOMM Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is for conference travel support and proposes to provide travel support for under-represented graduate students to attend the Networking for Networking Women (N2Women) event and SIGCOMM 2016. SIGCOMM is the flagship conference for networking, and participation in the conference provides a great opportunity for graduate students. Attending SIGCOMM not only exposes students to leading-edge research in the field, but also provides an opportunity to interact with senior researchers. Active participation can be challenging for students who are first-time attendees and know few people within the SIGCOMM community, which is especially common for under-represented students since there are few other minority participants at the conference. The N2Women event, co-located with the conference, aims to make it easier for the students to fully participate in the conference. Active participation in SIGCOMM is an effective way to expose students to new ideas and inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields.

The requested travel funds will allow more under-represented students to attend N2Women events, participate in a high-quality technical conference, and interact with senior researchers. This requested travel funds will help foster the under-represented minority community at SIGCOMM and promote a friendly environment for minority students to develop their career. It is expected that the impact to the students careers from attending the N2Women event and the SIGCOMM conference to be substantial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to start an N2Women dinner event at Sigcomm, a day before the conference, to provide under-represented students and students participating for the first time encouragement and advice on conference participation. Active participation can be challenging for students who are first-time attendees and know few people within the SIGCOMM community, which is especially common for underrepresented students since there are few other minority participants at the conference. NSF provided travel funds to support students to attend the N2Women dinner and the Sigcomm conference. The funds were used to support four students to attend Sigcomm 2018 held in Bucharest, Hungary from August 20 to 25th 2018.


Intellectual Merit: The project provided travel support for under-represented graduate students to attend the N2Women event and SIGCOMM 2016. The N2Women event was being organized for the first time   The N2Women event, co-located with the conference was aimed to make it easier for the students to fully participate in the conference. The roll over funds were used to provide travel support to four female students to attend Sigcomm 2018 and the N2Women dinner colocated with Sigcomm.
One significant outcome of this project is that the N2Women event is now being organized at Sigcomm every year. Other conferences are also arranging a similar event (e.g., Mobicom 2020). The idea of providing a friendly and supportive environment for first-time (and under-represented) students is now understood to be helpful. A survey was conducted at the end of the N2Women dinner in 2016, and the result of the survey showed the importance of this event for students. 


Broader Impact: The requested travel funds allowed under-represented students to attend the N2Women dinner and Sigcomm 2018. Participating in a high-quality technical conference, and interacting with senior researchers is an important part of the PhD process. The award helped foster the under-represented minority community at SIGCOMM and promote a friendly environment for minority students to develop their career. We expect the impact to the students careers from attending the N2Women event and the SIGCOMM conference to be substantial.
